8-й армійський корпус | image=8-й армійський корпус (2009).jpg | image_size = 150 |caption=Patch of the 8th Army Corps |dates=1 December 1993Надруковано: 'Народна армія'. – 2009. – 30 квітня via http://sammler.ru/index.php?showtopic=65121 – 15 March 2015 |country={{flag|Ukraine}} |allegiance= |branch=[[Ukrainian Ground Forces]] |type=[[Corps]] |role=Rapid reaction[http://www.mil.gov.ua/index.php?lang=ua&part=news&sub=read&id=5842 Новини Управління Прес-служби МО] |size= |command_structure= |garrison=[[Chernihiv Oblast]]
[[Kiev Oblast]]
[[Lviv Oblast]]
[[Zhytomyr Oblast]][http://www.mil.gov.ua/index.php?lang=ua&part=news&sub=read&id=7538 Новини Управління Прес-служби МО] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218230829/http://www.mil.gov.ua/index.php?lang=ua&part=news&sub=read&id=7538 |date=18 February 2012 }} |garrison_label= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |colors_label= |march= |mascot= |equipment= |equipment_label= |battles= |anniversaries=6 June 1946 |decorations=[[Order of the Red Star]] |battle_honours= |commander1=[[Lieutenant General]] [[Petro Lytvyn]] |commander1_label=Commanding officer |commander2=[[Major General]] Victor Myzhenko[http://uamedia.visti.net/ Our Army Magazine] |commander2_label=Second-in-command |commander3= |commander3_label= |notable_commanders= }} The '''8th Army Corps''' was one of three army corps of the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces]]. The Corps was headquartered in [[Zhytomyr]], Ukraine. In 2015 all army corps were dissolved and their units were transferred under jurisdiction of the operation command. On 1 December 1993, after the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], the 8th Army Corps was formed by the redesignation of the [[8th Tank Army]]. The 23rd Tank Division at [[Ovruch]] became the 6065th Base for Storage of Weapons and Equipment and the 117th Training Tank Division later became the 119th District Training Centre. The 30th Tank Division became a Ukrainian mechanised brigade. In March 2015, the 8th Army Corps was disbanded and its subordinate units transferred to other commands.{{Cite web|title = Новоград-Волинський: Коротко про головне|url = http://vybory.osp-ua.info/mista-idxnews-95730.html|website = vybory.osp-ua.info|access-date = 2016-02-12|language = Ukrainian|trans-title = Novohrad-Volynskyi: General News Summary|date = 20 March 2015|publisher = Institute of Society Transformation}} ==Structure== * [[File:8-й армійський корпус (2009).jpg|23px]] 8th Army Corps ** [[File:UA 1 Armored Brigade New.png|23px]] [[1st Armored Brigade (Ukraine)|1st Armored Brigade]] ([[Honcharivske]]) ** [[File:UA 30 Mechanized Brigade New.png|23px]] [[30th Mechanized Brigade (Ukraine)|30th Mechanized Brigade]] ([[Novohrad-Volynskyi]]) ** [[File:72-а механізована бригада.png|23px]] [[72nd Guards Mechanized Brigade|72nd Mechanized Brigade]] ([[Bila Tserkva]]) ** [[File:95-а аеромобільна бригада.jpg|23px]] [[95th Airmobile Brigade (Ukraine)|95th Airmobile Brigade]] ([[Zhytomyr]]) ** [[File:26-а артилерійська бригада (2008).png|23px]] [[26th Artillery Brigade]] ([[Berdychiv]])The 117th TTD was succeeded by the 62nd mechanized brigade, based on which, in turn, was created 26th Artillery Brigade (based on the Directive of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine from 18.06.2004 № 312/1/014 year). Source Ruwiki 117 GRD. ** [[File:27-й реактивний артилерійський полк.png|frameless|28x28px]]27th Reactive Artillery Regiment - ([[Sumy]]) ** [[File:UA 3 Army Aviation Regiment New.png|23px]] [[3rd Army Aviation Regiment (Ukraine)|3rd Army Aviation Regiment]] ([[Brody]]) ** [[File:UA 12 Engineer Regiment New.png|23px]] 12th Engineer Regiment ([[Novohrad-Volynskyi]]) ** [[File:UA 93 Signal Regiment New.png|23px]] 93rd Signal Regiment ([[Zhytomyr]]) ** [[File:UA 347 Communications Center New.png|23px]] 347th Communications Center ([[Zhytomyr]]) ** [[File:UA 54 Radio Technical Battalion New.png|23px]] 54th Radio Technical Battalion ([[Zhytomyr]]) ** Other Corps Units ==Commanders== {| class="wikitable" !rowspan="2"| Rank !rowspan="2"| Name !colspan="2"| Position held |- ! End |- | [[Lieutenant General]] | Oleh Romanenko{{cite journal|last=|first=|date=December 2009|title=Army Corps Commanders|url=http://www.vu.mil.gov.ua/pdf/2009-12.pdf|journal=Viysko Ukrayiny (Army of Ukraine)|language=Ukrainian|volume=12|page=64|pages=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304085126/http://www.vu.mil.gov.ua/pdf/2009-12.pdf|archive-date=4 March 2011|via=}} | June 1993 | January 1997 |- | [[Major General]] | Viacheslav Zabolotnyi | February 1997 | May 2000 |- | [[Lieutenant General]] | [[Hryhoriy Pedchenko]] | May 2000 | December 2002 |- | [[Major General]] | Anatoliy Pushniakov | December 2002 | November 2004 |- | [[Lieutenant General]] | Serhiy Ostrovskyi | November 2004 | May 2010 |- | [[Major General]] | [[Viktor Muzhenko]] | May 2010 | May 2012 |- | [[Lieutenant General]] | [[Petro Lytvyn]] | May 2012 | March 2015 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://8korpus.in.ua/main Official website] {{Ukrainian Ground Forces}} {{8th Army Corps (Ukraine)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[Category:Corps of Ukraine]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1993]] [[Category:Military units and formations disestablished in 2015]] {{UGF-stub}}

page.title: Azerbaijan State Theatre of Young Spectators

revision.text:
{{Infobox building |name = Azerbaijan State Theatre of Young Spectators |native_name= |image = Azərbaycan Dövlət Gənc Tamaşaçılar Teatrı.jpg |caption = |former_names = |building_type = |architectural_style = |structural_system = |location = [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] |owner = |current_tenants = |landlord = |coordinates = {{coord|40.3740|49.8428|display=inline,title}} |map_type = Azerbaijan |start_date = 1928 |completion_date = |demolition_date = |height = |diameter = |other_dimensions = |floor_count = |floor_area = |main_contractor = |architect = |structural_engineer = |services_engineer = |civil_engineer = |other_designers = |quantity_surveyor = |awards = }} '''Azerbaijan State Theater of Young Spectators''' ({{Lang-az|Azərbaycan Dövlət Gənc Tamaşaçılar Teatrı}}) is a theatre located in the centre of [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=Theatre of young spectator |url=http://www.bakucitylife.com/catalog.php?lang=&pt2=1&nid=48 |publisher=Bakucitylife.com |date= |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107130003/http://bakucitylife.com/catalog.php?lang=&pt2=1&nid=48 |archivedate=2012-01-07 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Theatre of young spectators |url=http://eurovision.az/panorama/genc_tamasacilar/?lng=en |publisher=Eurovision.az |date= |accessdate= }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = In the Azerbaijan State Theatre of the Young Spectator has passed the international conference | url=http://en.baku-art.com/index.php?newsid=4234 | publisher=baku-art.az | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
==History of the theater== Azerbaijan State Theater of Young Spectators (ASTYS) was founded in 1928 as Baku Children’s Theater according to the Decision of the Commissariat of Public Enlightenment of Azerbaijan dated September 20, 1928. The initial group of actors and directors of the theatre included Aghadadash Gurbanov, Mammadagha Dadashov, Yusif Eminli, Mina Abdullayeva, Yusif Dadashov, Susanna Majidova, Javahir Iskandarov, Suleyman Alasgarov, Huseynagha Sadikhov, Karim Hasanov, Zafar Nematov, Maharram Hashimov, and Alimammad Atayev.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=history|title=History of theatre|last=|first=|date=|website=www.tyuz.az|language=|archive-url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=history|archive-date=2018-07-24|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref>
The Russian section of the theater started its activity on November 6, 1928 when a [[Russia]]n troupe made a performance of the play “Five people” by N.Smirnov and S.Serbakov here for the first time.<ref name=":0" /> An Azerbaijani troupe, created on the basis of drama circle of [[Young Pioneer organization of the Soviet Union|pioneers]] affiliated with the Baku Club of Sailors became a member of this theatre, in 1930.
Azerbaijani section started on January 30, 1930 with “Against Red tie" by N.Ivanter.<ref name=":0" />
In the first years of its existence, the theatre staged plays of [[List of Russian-language playwrights|Russian writers]], which were constituted the repertoire of Young Spectators' Theatres of other cities of the [[Soviet Union|USSR]]. In the 1930s, plays of Azerbaijani dramatists were included in the repertoire of the theatre: ''In the streets'' by Jafarov and Melik-Yeganov (1932), ''Nargiz'' (1936), ''Ayaz'' (1937), ''Gizil Gush'' (Golden bird) by Seyidzade (1938), and ''Mammad the Partisan'' by Isgandarov and Sabit Rahman (1939).<ref>{{Cite news |title=Азербайджанский театр юного зрителя (ТЮЗ) |url=http://news.day.az/showbiz/16842_print.html |publisher=Day.az |date= |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406205655/http://news.day.az/showbiz/16842_print.html |archivedate=2012-04-06 |df= }}</ref>
In 1936, the theater was named after [[Maxim Gorky]].
Baku Children’s Theater was renamed based on the order of the Commissariat of Public Enlightenment of Azerbaijan on July 18, 1936 and has been called “Azerbaijan State Theater of Young Spectators” since then. The ASTYS was awarded with the Republic Lenin Komsomol Prize Laureate in 1978 and the Order of Honor in 1979.<ref name=":0" />
Azerbaijan State Youth Theater and Baku Camera Theater were united to ASTYS according to the decisions of [[Cabinet of Azerbaijan|Cabinet of Ministers of Azerbaijan]] dated respectively on March 19 and September 30 in 2009.<ref name=":0" />
Children's and Youth Theaters of Azerbaijan State Theater of Young Spectators was became the member of the [[ASSITEJ|International Association of Theater for Children and Young People]] (ASSITEJ) in May 2011 and national center of [[ASSITEJ]] was opened in [[Azerbaijan]] after a while.<ref name=":0" />
The small stage of the Theater considered for mono and small volume plays was inaugurated in December 2013.<ref name=":0" />
== Festivals == The ASTYS's troupe has been attending international theatre festivals since 2006:<ref name=":0" /> {| class="wikitable" |'''Events''' |'''Date''' |'''Location''' |'''Performance''' |- Ganjavi]], “Mother Goose” by [[Rasul Rza]] and “Play and dance” by Iskandar Joshgun |- |[[TRT International April 23 Children's Festival|International April 23 Children's Festival]] |April 2008 |[[Ankara]] and [[Iğdır|Ighdir]], [[Turkey]] |“Grandma’s trick” by Ahmad Oruj |- |9th International Theater Festival of Turkic-speaking countries |May-June 2009 |[[Kazan]], [[Russia]] |“Pary jadu” by [[Abdurrahim bey Hagverdiyev]] |- |12th International Festival of Antique Art |June 2010 |[[Simferopol]] |"Aesop" by [[Guilherme Figueiredo|Guilherme Figueredo]] |- |32nd International Festival "Fajr" |[[Orenburg|Orenburgh]], [[Russia]] |"I came, Girls" ("War") by [[Lars Norén|Lars Noren]] |- |2nd International Martin McDonagh Festival |October 2016 |[[Perm]], [[Russia]] |"[[The Beauty Queen of Leenane]]" by [[Martin McDonagh]] |- |11th International Mono-spectacles Festival "Atspindys" |October |[[Vilnius]] and [[Visaginas]], [[Lithuania]] |"Without words" by [[Samuel Beckett]] |- |3rd International Theater Festival "Hot Heart" |April 2017 |[[Kineshma]], [[Ivanovo Oblast]], [[Russia]] |“[[Diary of a Madman (short story)|Diary of a Madman]]” by [[Nikolai Gogol]] |- |14th International Folks Art Festival “Friendship Wreath” |June-July 2017 |[[Babruysk|Bobruysk]], [[Mogilev Oblast]], [[Belarus]] |"[[Der Kontrabaß|Contrabass]]" by [[Patrick Süskind]] |- |6th International Festival “Tuganlig” of Turkic speaking theaters |September 2017 |[[Ufa]], [[Russia]] |“Punishment” by Tamara Valiyeva |- |1st International Theater Festival "Keyeda" for children and youth |September-October 2017 |[[Elista]], [[Russia]] |“Tik-tik khanim“ by [[Abdulla Shaig]] |- |“Maria” International Mono-Performances Festival |October 2017 |[[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]] |"[[Der Kontrabaß|Contrabass]]" by [[Patrick Süskind]] |- |36th International Theater Festival “Fajr” |January 2018 |[[Tehran]], [[Iran]] |“Punishment” by Tamara Valiyeva |- |8th International Theater Olympics |March 2018 |[[India]] |“Punishment” by Tamara Valiyeva |}
== Repertoire == ASTYS’s repertoire includes plays of foreign ([[William Shakespeare]], [[Martin McDonagh]], [[Hans Christian Andersen]], [[Aleksey Nikolayevich Tolstoy|Aleksey Tolstoy]]) and domestic playwrights, such as [[Huseyn Javid]], [[Jafar Jabbarly|Jafar Jabbarli]], [[Mirza Fatali Akhundov|Mirza Fatali Akhundzada]], [[Ilyas Afandiyev]], [[Suleyman Rustam]], [[Abdurrahim bey Hagverdiyev]], [[Abdulla Shaig]], [[Nizami Ganjavi]], [[Suleyman Sani Akhundov]] for both adults and schoolchildren.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=current_repertoire|title=Current repertoire|last=|first=|date=|website=www.tyuz.az|language=az|archive-url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=current_repertoire|archive-date=2018-07-24|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref>[[File:"III Riçard" tamaşası (Azərbaycan Dövlət Gənc Tamaşaçılar Teatrının tamaşası, 31 oktyabr 2015-ci il).jpg|thumb|250px|Richard III (Spectacle of Azerbaijan State Theatre of Young Spectators). Directed by Jannat Salimova]] Classical drama plays of Russian and foreign dramatists, plays of the Soviet writers and dramatists were also staged on the theater, such as ''[[The Government Inspector]]'' by [[Nikolai Gogol]], ''[[Servant of Two Masters]]'' by [[William Shakespeare]], and ''[[How the Steel Was Tempered]]'' by [[Nikolai Ostrovsky]].<ref>{{Cite news | title = Программа Азербайджанского государственного театра юного зрителя на декабрь 2011 года | url=http://www.baku.ru/enc-show.php?id=124851&cmm_id=149 | publisher=Baku Pages | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
== Projects ==
* "The theater, education and morality"; * "We love the theater"; * "The first student card, the joy of the first acquaintance with the theater"; * "The personalities in the Heights"; * "Martyrs are immortal, homeland is indivisible"; * "I want to talk about theater".<ref name=":0" />
==Theatre personnel== Managing director of the ASTYS is Naida Ismayilzada.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=rehberlik|title=Management of the theatre|last=|first=|date=|website=www.tyuz.az|language=az|archive-url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=rehberlik|archive-date=2018-07-24|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref> Bahram Osmanov is the chief director of the theatre.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=bediishura|title=Personnel of the ASTYS|last=|first=|date=|website=www.tyuz.az|language=az|archive-url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=bediishura|archive-date=2018-07-24|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref>
=== Actors === Yasin Garayev, Aghakhan Salmanli, Almaz Mustafayeva, Atabala Safarov, Naiba Allahverdiyeva, Gurban Ismayilov and others.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=aktyorlar|title=Actors|last=|first=|date=|website=www.tyuz.az|language=az|archive-url=http://www.tyuz.az/az.php?go=aktyorlar|archive-date=2018-07-24|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref>

{{Infobox stadium | name = B&W Hallerne | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = B&W Hallerne 2014-04-27 3.jpg | caption = B&W Hallerne in April 2014 | fullname = Burmeister & Wain Halls | former_names = | location = [[Refshaleøen, Copenhagen|Refshaleøen]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] | coordinates = {{coord|55|41|35|N|12|37|0|E|type:isle_region:DK_source:dawiki|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1960s | opened = | renovated = 2011 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Burmeister & Wain]] (until 1996)
[[Refshaleøen, Copenhagen|Refshaleøen]]'s Property Company (1996–present) | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 10,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = | website = }} '''B&W Hallerne''' (English: ''The B&W Halls'') is a former industrial complex located on the island of [[Refshaleøen, Copenhagen|Refshaleøen]] in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. Built in the early 1960s by [[Burmeister & Wain]], the complex consists of two large halls which were used to build ships until 1996.{{cite web|title=B&W Hallerne - From industrial stronghold to Eurovision venue|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=89903&_t=bandw_hallerne_-_from_industrial_stronghold_to_eurovision_venue|publisher=Eurovision.tv|accessdate=3 September 2013}} Currently, the facilities are used for culture and entertainment activities.{{cite web|title=Sharing Copenhagen with the World 2014 |url=http://www.dr.dk/NR/rdonlyres/004fd35d/pymdtkwejputvpcoekjtmbvyxdmbumop/KbhsbudESC2014.pdf |first=Sebastian |last=Goos |work=Wonderful Copenhagen |accessdate=29 June 2013 |language=Danish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224144631/http://www.dr.dk/NR/rdonlyres/004fd35d/pymdtkwejputvpcoekjtmbvyxdmbumop/KbhsbudESC2014.pdf |archivedate=24 December 2013 |df= }} On 2 September 2013, Danish public broadcaster [[DR (broadcaster)|DR]] announced that it had chosen B&W Hallerne as the host venue for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2014]].{{cite web|title=Copenhagen announced as host city of Eurovision 2014|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=89733&_t=copenhagen_announced_as_host_city_of_eurovision_2014#comments|publisher=Eurovision.tv|accessdate=2 September 2013}} The contest was held at the Section Hall 2, which was converted into a music venue with a capacity for 10,000 spectators. The surrounding buildings and areas were transformed into "Eurovision Island" which was used for additional services related to the contest. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{commons category inline}} *[http://refshaleoen.dk/ Refshaleøen's Official Website] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Eurovision Song Contest]]
Venue | before=[[Malmö Arena]]
[[Malmö]] | after= [[Wiener Stadthalle]]
[[Vienna]] | years='''[[Eurovision Song Contest 2014|2014]]''' }} {{s-end}} {{Eurovision Song Contest}} {{DEFAULTSORT:BandW Hallerne}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Culture in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Music venues in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest venues]] {{Denmark-stub}} {{Eurovision-stub}}

revision.text:
{{food safety}} The '''''Codex Alimentarius''''' is a collection of internationally recognized standards, codes of practice, guidelines, and other recommendations relating to [[food]]s, food production, and [[food safety]].
Its name is derived from the [[Codex Alimentarius Austriacus]].<ref>[http://www.fao.org/docrep/v7700t/v7700t09.htm ''Codex Alimentarius'': how it all began] Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations website. Accessed 6 September 2012.</ref> Its texts are developed and maintained by the '''''Codex Alimentarius'' Commission''', a body that was established in early November 1961 by the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the [[United Nations]] (FAO), was joined by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) in June 1962, and held its first session in Rome in October 1963.<ref>[http://www.codexalimentarius.org/about-codex/the-foundation-history-of-codex/en/ Codex timeline from 1945 to the present]</ref> The Commission's main goals are to [[consumer protection|protect the health of consumers]] and ensure fair practices in the international food trade. The Codex Alimentarius is recognized by the [[World Trade Organization]] as an international reference point for the [[Dispute resolution|resolution of disputes]] concerning food safety and consumer protection.<ref name="wto.org">[http://www.wto.org/english/docs_e/legal_e/15sps_01_e.htm Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures] World Trade Organization. Accessed 3 September 2008.</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">[ftp://ftp.fao.org/codex/Publications/understanding/Understanding_EN.pdf Understanding the Codex Alimentarius]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Preface. Third Edition. Published in 2006 by the World Health Organization and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Accessed 3 September 2008.</ref>
As of 2012, there were 186 members of the Codex Alimentarius Commission: 186 member countries and one member organization, the [[European Union]] (EU). There were 215 Codex observers: 49 [[intergovernmental organization]]s, 150 [[non-governmental organization]]s, and 16 [[United Nations System|United Nations organizations]].<ref>[http://www.codexalimentarius.org/members-observers/observers/en/ Observers]</ref>
==Scope== The Codex Alimentarius covers all foods, whether processed, semi-processed or [[raw food|raw]]. In addition to standards for specific foods, the Codex Alimentarius contains general standards covering matters such as [[Food labelling regulations|food labeling]], food [[hygiene]], [[food additives]] and [[pesticide]] residues, and procedures for assessing the safety of foods derived from modern [[biotechnology]]. It also contains guidelines for the management of official i.e. governmental [[import]] and [[export]] inspection and [[certification]] systems for foods.
The Codex Alimentarius is published in the six [[official languages of the United Nations]]: [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Russian language|Russian]].<ref>{{cite web|title=CODEX Alimentarius: Understanding Codex|url=http://www.codexalimentarius.org/about-codex/understanding-codex/en/|publisher=FAO and WHO|accessdate=6 September 2012|year=1999|quote=Understanding Codex is available in English, French, Spanish, Arabic, Chinese and Russian version.}}</ref> Not all texts are available in all languages.
===General texts=== * [[Food labelling]] (general standard, guidelines on [[nutrition]] labelling, guidelines on labelling claims) * [[Food additive]]s (general standard including authorized uses, specifications for food grade chemicals) * [[Contaminant]]s in foods (general standard, tolerances for specific contaminants including [[radionuclide]]s, [[aflatoxin]]s and other [[mycotoxin]]s) * [[Pesticide]] and veterinary chemical residues in foods (maximum residue limits) * [[Risk assessment]] procedures for determining the safety of foods derived from biotechnology ([[DNA]]-modified plants, DNA-modified [[micro-organism]]s, [[allergens]]) * Food [[hygiene]] (general principles, codes of hygienic practice in specific industries or food handling establishments, guidelines for the use of the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point or “[[HACCP]]” system) * Methods of analysis and sampling
===Specific standards=== * [[Meat]] products (fresh, frozen, processed meats and [[poultry]]) * [[Fish]] and [[fishery]] products (marine, fresh water and [[aquaculture]]) * [[Milk]] and milk products * Foods for special [[Diet (nutrition)|dietary]] uses (including [[infant formula]] and [[baby food]]s) * Fresh and processed [[vegetable]]s, [[fruit]]s, and [[fruit juice]]s * [[Cereal]]s and derived products, dried [[legume]]s * Fats, oils and derived products such as [[margarine]] * Miscellaneous food products ([[chocolate]], [[sugar]], [[honey]], [[mineral water]])
==Controversy== The controversy over the Codex Alimentarius relates to a perception that it is a mandatory [[Technical standard|standard]] for the safety of food, including vitamin and mineral supplements. Supporters of the Codex Alimentarius say that it is a voluntary reference standard for food and that there is no obligation on countries to adopt Codex standards as a member of either Codex or any other international trade organization. From the point of view of its opponents, however, one of the main causes of concern is that the Codex Alimentarius is recognized by the [[World Trade Organization]] as an international reference standard for the resolution of disputes concerning food safety and consumer protection.<ref name="wto.org"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> Proponents argue that the use of Codex Alimentarius during international disputes does not exclude the use of other references or scientific studies as evidence of food safety and consumer protection.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}}
It is reported that in 1996 the German delegation put forward a proposal that no herb, vitamin or mineral should be sold for preventive or therapeutic reasons, and that supplements should be reclassified as drugs.<ref name="guardian.co.uk">[https://www.theguardian.com/society/2002/sep/14/medicineandhealth.lifeandhealth 'Health supplements: R.I.P.'. The Guardian newspaper, UK.] Published 14 September 2002. Accessed 2 August 2008</ref> The proposal was agreed, but protests halted its implementation.<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/> The 28th Session of the Codex Alimentarius Commission was subsequently held July 4–9, 2005.<ref>[ftp://ftp.fao.org/codex/alinorm05/al28_41e.pdf Codex Alimentarius Commission 28th Session, FAO Headquarters, Rome, Italy, 4-9 July, 2005. Official report.]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Among the many issues discussed were the ''Guidelines for [[Vitamin]] and Mineral [[Dietary supplement|Food Supplements]]'',<ref name="codexalimentarius.net">[http://www.codexalimentarius.net/download/standards/10206/cxg_055e.pdf Codex Guidelines for Vitamin and Mineral Food Supplements]</ref> which were adopted during the meeting as new global safety guidelines: The guidelines state that "people should...be encouraged to select a balanced diet from food before considering any vitamin and mineral supplement. In cases where the intake from the diet is insufficient or where consumers consider their diet requires supplementation, vitamin and mineral food supplements serve to supplement the daily diet."<ref name="codexalimentarius.net"/><ref name="un2005">{{cite web|title=UN commission adopts safety guidelines for vitamin and food supplements|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=14974&Cr=codex&Cr1|publisher=United Nations News Centre|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=11 July 2005}}</ref> This text has been the subject of considerable controversy among proponents of [[dietary supplements]]. Many countries regulate such substances as therapeutic goods or [[pharmaceutical]]s or by some other category, without requiring them to be shown to be medically useful.{{Citation needed|date=September 2012}} The text does not seek to ban supplements, but subjects them to labeling and packaging requirements, sets criteria for the setting of maximum and minimum dosage levels, and requires that safety and efficacy are considered when determining ingredient sources. The [[United Nations]]' [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] (FAO) and [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) will implement these criteria with "labelling to stop consumers overdosing on vitamin and mineral food supplements." The Codex Alimentarius Commission (CAC) has said that the Guidelines call "for labelling that contains information on maximum consumption levels of vitamin and mineral food supplements." The WHO has also said that the Guidelines "ensure that consumers receive beneficial health effects from vitamins and minerals."<ref name=un2005 />
In 2004, similarities were noted between the EU's [[Food Supplements Directive]] and the Codex Alimentarius draft guidelines for vitamin and mineral supplements'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nil by mouth|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2004/feb/29/health.shopping|publisher=The Observer, Guardian UK|accessdate=17 September 2012|author=Rose Shepherd|date=29 February 2004}}</ref> Additional controversy has been expressed by proponents of ecologically and socially sustainable agriculture and food systems, such as the [[Slow Food]] movement,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.slowfood.com/international/1/about-us|title=Slow Food International|last=|first=|date=|website=Slow Food International|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905122146/http://www.slowfood.com/international/1/about-us|archive-date=2012-09-05|dead-url=yes|access-date=|df=}}</ref> although the Slow Food movement has become more closely aligned with the EU.<ref>[http://slowfood.com About us, Slow Food] "Slow Food gratefully acknowledges funding support from the European Commission."</ref> In addition, the Manifesto on the Future of Food stated that "bureaucracies like the World Trade Organization, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, and the Codex Alimentarius have codified policies designed to serve the interests of global agribusiness above all others, while actively undermining the rights of farmers and consumers".<ref>{{cite web | title=Manifesto on the Future of Food | author=The International Commission on the Future of Food and Agriculture | date=July 15, 2003 | url=http://www.farmingsolutions.org/pdfdb/manifestoinglese.pdf | deadurl=bot: unknown | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050602203751/http://www.farmingsolutions.org/pdfdb/manifestoinglese.pdf | archivedate=June 2, 2005 | df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[FDA Food Safety Modernization Act]] * [[Food Chemicals Codex]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.codexalimentarius.org/ Codex Alimentarius - official website] * [http://www.fao.org/docrep/w9114e/w9114e00.HTM 'Understanding the Codex Alimentarius'] Published in 2005 by the World Health Organization and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Accessed 4 May 2007. * [http://ssrn.com/abstract=903408 "Authority and Legitimacy in Global Governance: Deliberation, Institutional Differentiation, and the Codex Alimentarius"] Michael Livermore, 81 NYU Law Review 766 (2006) * [http://www.organic-standards.info/en/ Organic Standards] Database to compare the EU regulation on organic farming, the National Organic Program (NOP) of the US and the guidelines for the production, processing, labeling and marketing of organically produced food of the Codex Alimentarius * [https://archive.is/20121214150801/http://www.fsis.usda.gov/codex/Codex_CAC/index.asp 'Codex Alimentarius Commission'] Documents for The 35th Session of the Codex Alimentarius Commission. Published 13 July 2012 by the Food Inspection & Safety Service of the U.S.D.A. Accessed 6 September 2012.

revision.text:
The '''Constitution (Amendment No. 11) Act 1929''' was an Act amending the [[Constitution of the Irish Free State]]. It amended Article 34 of the constitution regarding the filling of casual vacancies in [[Seanad Eireann]].
As enacted, Article 34 provided that vacancies would be filled by a vote of the Seanad.<ref>http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1922/act/1/enacted/en/print.html</ref>
Under the 11th amendment, the provision was changed to provide that the vote would be by members of [[Dail Eireann]] and Seanad Eireann voting together (which remains the procedure to this day under the 1937 constitution).<ref>http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1929/act/34/section/1/enacted/en/html#sec1</ref>
The Act became obsolete on the repeal of the 1922 Constitution by the [[Constitution of Ireland]] in 1937, and has formally been repealed by the [[Statute Law Revision Act 2016]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oireachtas.ie/documents/bills28/bills/2016/1616/B16b16S.pdf |format=PDF |title=Statute Law Revision Bill 2016 |website=Oireachtas.ie |accessdate=2017-01-02}}</ref>
==References==

revision.text:
{{Politics of Kenya}} '''Kenya's 1963 independence constitution''' was based on the standard "[[Lancaster House Conferences (Kenya)|Lancaster House template]]" used for the former British colonies in Africa, was subject to early amendments, and was replaced in 1969.
Under the [[Constitution of Kenya]], the [[British monarch]], [[Queen Elizabeth II]], was represented as [[head of state]] by a [[Governor-General of Kenya]]. The Constitution also provided for a [[bicameral]] [[Parliament of Kenya|parliament]], the [[National Assembly of Kenya|National Assembly]], consisting of the [[Senate of Kenya|Senate]] and the [[House of Representatives of Kenya|House of Representatives]]. Each [[Provinces of Kenya|province]] had an elected assembly.
In 1964, the Constitution was amended to make the country a [[republic]] with the [[President of Kenya|President]] as both head of state and head of government, and in 1966, the membership of the Senate and House of Representatives was combined to form a [[unicameral]] National Assembly.
==See also== * [[Constitution of Kenya]], 2010 * [[Constitutional Reforms in Kenya]] * [[Kenyan constitutional referendum, 2005]]
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160303210309/http://www.kenyadocex.com/politics/the-constitution-of-kenya-1963/ 1963 Constitution]

{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Luxembourg}} "Frère Jacques" | image = | caption = | year = 1977 | country = Luxembourg | artist = Anne-Marie Besse | as = Anne-Marie B. | with = | language = French | languages = | composer = [[Pierre Cour]], Guy Béart | lyricist = [[Pierre Cour]], Guy Béart | conductor = Johnny Arthey | place = 16th | points = 17 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1977lu from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Chansons pour ceux qui s'aiment | prev_link = Chansons pour ceux qui s'aiment | next = Parlez-vous français? | next_link = Parlez-vous français? }} '''"Frère Jacques"''' ("Brother John") was the [[Luxembourg]]ish entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1977]], performed in [[French language|French]] by [[France|French]] singer [[Anne-Marie Besse]].
As the title suggests, the [[disco]]-influenced song contains several references to [[Frère Jacques|the nursery rhyme of the same name]]; ''"Frère Jacques, dormez-vous?" ("Brother John, are you sleeping?") "J'entends les cloches qui sonnent" ("I can hear the bells ringing")'' and ''"Tu aurais bien mieux à faire que de jouer au grand frère..." ("There are so much better things for you to do than pretending to be my big brother....")''. The singer compares the childish rhyme to her current adulthood, singing about how she longs to have a relationship with some of Jacques/John's friends; ''"I'm not a child anymore, you know"''. The song ends with the line ''"Frère Jacques, réveille-toi et viens dormir avec moi..." ("Brother John, wake up and come sleep with me...")''.
The song was performed seventh on the night, following [[Germany]]'s [[Silver Convention]] with "[[Telegram (song)|Telegram]]" and preceding [[Portugal]]'s [[Os Amigos]] with "[[Portugal no coração]]". At the close of voting, it had received 17 points, placing 16th in a field of 18.
It was succeeded as [[Luxembourg in the Eurovision Song Contest|Luxembourgish representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1978|1978 Contest]] by [[Baccara]] with "[[Parlez-vous français?]]".
==Sources and external links== * [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=293 Official Eurovision Song Contest site, history by year, 1977] * [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1977lu Detailed info & lyrics, The Diggiloo Thrush, "Frère Jacques"]
{{Luxembourg in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1977}}

revision.text:
{{other uses|Hadiya (disambiguation)}} '''Hadiya ('''ሃድያ: Hadiya or Hadiyya) is the [[Ethiopian]] ethnic group of people who speak the [[Hadiyya language]]. However, proper historical definition of Hadiya people includes a number of Ethiopian ethnic groups currently known by other names according to ethnologist Ulrich Braukämper who lived in various parts of southern-central Ethiopia for over four years during his research <ref name="Braukämper2012">{{cite book | last = Braukämper | first = Ulrich | title = A history of the Hadiyya in Southern Ethiopia | publisher = Harrassowitz Verlag | location = Wiesbaden | year = 2012 | isbn = 9783447068048 }}</ref> In his book titled A history of the Hadiyya in Southern Ethiopia he establishes linkages to ancient [[Hadiya Kingdom]] the current ethnic groups of [[Halaba people]] (Allaaba or Alaba), Silt'e or Selte [[Silt'e people]], "Hadiyya" clans of the Arisi-Oromo & Ittuu-Oromo, and "Clans of Hadiyya origin in Wälaytta" in addition to current speakers of [[Hadiyya language]] in [[Hadiya Zone]] & the Libidoo (speakers of [[Libido language]] dialect) of [[Mareko (woreda)|Mareko]] in [[Gurage Zone]].
The [[Hadiya Zone]] is named after the Hadiya people, whose homeland covers part of this [[Zones of Ethiopia|administrative division]]. The 2007 Ethiopian national census reported that 1,269,382 people (or 1.5% of the population) identified themselves as Hadiya, of whom 150,087 were urban inhabitants. The [[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and People's Region]] is home to 93.9% of this people.<ref>[http://www.csa.gov.et/index.php?option=com_rubberdoc&view=doc&id=264&format=raw&Itemid=521 "Census 2007, Country Level"] now it is projected as reaching 3 million, Table 3.1</ref>
== Notable individuals == * [[Beyene Petros]] - is a professor of Biology at Addis Ababa University, former member of the Ethiopian House of People's Representatives, former chairman of Forum for Democratic Dialogue in Ethiopia or Medrek (FDDE), and its current head of Public Relations & External Affairs, and chairman of Ethiopian Social Democratic Party(ESDP), a member party of Medrek. * Bezabih Petros * Asefa Abiyu - Ethiopian federal police commissioner General * [[Eleni of Ethiopia]]
==See also== * [[Hadiya Sultanate]] * [[Hadiya Zone]] * [[Hadiyya language]]
== References == {{reflist}}

{{ethiopia-ethno-group-stub}}

The '''Hindu Council of Russia''' represents members of the [[Hindu]] religion in [[Russia]]. The council was created on December 19, 2011, in light of the [[Bhagavad Gita trial in Russia]], by "Hindus from [[India]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Mauritius]], [[Nepal]] and other countries residing in Russia."<ref name=ET1>{{cite news|last=Lukin|first=Vladmiir|title=Russian Court suspends Bhagavad Gita verdict till December 28|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-12-20/news/30537987_1_sadhu-priya-das-bhagavad-gita-iskcon|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=[[The Economic Times|Economic Times]]|date=20 December 2011}}</ref> [[Sadhu Priya Das]] is the current chairman.<ref name=TOI>{{cite news|title=Russian prosecutors to move higher court on Gita|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Russian-prosecutors-to-move-higher-court-on-Gita/articleshow/11644042.cms|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=27 January 2012|agency=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]]}}</ref><ref name=Outlook>{{cite news|last=Shukla|first=Vinay|title=Bhagwat Gita ban: Russia suspends verdict till Dec 28|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=744859|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]]|date=19 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514185046/http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=744859|archivedate=14 May 2014|df=}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Hinduism in Russia]] * [[Hindu Forum of Britain]]

page.title: Historical Composition of the Peruvian Congress

revision.text:
This is a list of the composition of the [[Congress of the Republic of Peru]] since the adoption of the current [[Constitution of Peru]] in 1993 starting with the [[Peruvian general election, 1995#Congress|1995 elections]].
==Peruvian Congress of 1995-2000== {{main article|List of members of the Congress of Peru, 1995–2000|Peruvian general election, 1995}} On July 27, 1995 a new unicameral Congress was created with the following distribution by political party:
*[[Cambio 90|Change 90-New Majority]] ([[Alberto Fujimori]]): 67 seats *[[Union for Peru]] ([[Javier Pérez de Cuéllar]]): 17 seats *[[Peruvian Aprista Party]] ([[Mercedes Cabanillas]]): 8 seats *[[Independent Moralizing Front]] ([[Fernando Olivera]]): 6 seats *[[Democratic Convergence-Possible Country]] ([[Alejandro Toledo]]): 5 seats *[[Popular Action (Peru)|Popular Action]] ([[Raúl Diez Canseco]]): 4 seats *[[Christian People's Party (Peru)|Christian People's Party]] ([[Luis Bedoya Reyes]]): 3 seats *[[National Renewal (Peru)|National Renovation]] ([[Rafael Rey]]): 3 seats *[[United Left (Peru)|United Left]] ([[Agustín Haya de la Torre]]): 2 seats *OBRAS ([[Ricardo Belmont Cassinelli]]): 2 seats *FREPAP ([[Ezequiel Ataucusi Gamonal]]): 1 seat *National Front of Workers and Peasants ([[Roger Cáceres Velásquez]]): 1 seat *Agrarian Independent Movement (-): 1 seat
==Peruvian Congress of 2000-2001== {{main article|List of members of the Congress of Peru, 2000–2001|Peruvian general election, 2000}} On July 27, 2000 the Congress of the Republic was established. This Congressional period was marked with various episodes of members of Congress [[Party switching|switching their party affiliation]]. The following distribution marks seats by party at the end of the 2000-2001 term:
*Peru 2000 ([[Alberto Fujimori]]): 52 seats *[[Peru Possible]] ([[Alejandro Toledo]]): 29 seats *[[Independent Moralizing Front]] ([[Fernando Olivera]]): 9 seats *[[Somos Perú]]: 8 seats *[[Peruvian Aprista Party]]: 6 seats *[[National Solidarity (Peru)|National Solidarity]]): 5 seats *[[Avancemos]] ([[Federico Salas]]): 3 seats *[[Popular Action (Peru)|Popular Action]] ([[Víctor Andrés García Belaúnde]]): 3 seats *[[Union for Peru]] ([[Máximo San Román]]: 3 seats *FREPAP: 1 seat
==Peruvian Congress of 2001-2006 == {{main article|List of members of the Congress of Peru, 2001–2006|Peruvian general election, 2001}} On July 21, 2001 a new Congress of the Peruvian Republic was established the following is a distribution of Congress members by political party affiliation:
*[[Peru Possible]] ([[Alejandro Toledo Manrique|Alejandro Toledo]]): 35 seats *[[Peruvian Aprista Party]] ([[Alan García Pérez|Alan García]]): 28 seats *[[National Unity (Peru)|National Unity]] ([[Lourdes Flores]]): 12 seats *[[Independent Moralizing Front]] ([[Fernando Olivera Vega|Fernando Olivera]]): 7 seats *[[Somos Perú]]([[Alberto Andrade]]): 6 seats *Other parties: 27 seats
==Peruvian Congress of 2006-2011== {{main article|List of members of the Congress of Peru, 2006–2011|Peruvian general election, 2006}} A new Peruvian Congress of the Republic was established in July 2006 with the following distribution:
*[[Union for Peru]] ([[Ollanta Humala]]): 45 seats. *[[Peruvian Aprista Party]] ([[Alan García]]): 36 seats. *[[National Unity (Peru)|National Unity]] ([[Lourdes Flores]]): 17 seats. *[[Alliance for the Future (Peru)|Alliance for the Future]] ([[Martha Chávez]]): 13 seats. *[[Center Front]] ([[Valentín Paniagua Corazao|Valentín Paniagua]]): 5 seats. *[[Possible Peru]] ([[Alejandro Toledo Manrique|Alejandro Toledo]]): 2 seats. *[[National Restoration Party (Peru)|National Restoration]] ([[Humberto Lay Sun|Humberto Lay]]): 2 seats.
==Peruvian Congress of 2011-2016== {{main article|List of members of the Congress of Peru, 2011–2016|Peruvian general election, 2011}} *[[Peru Wins]] ([[Ollanta Humala]]): 47 seats. *[[Force 2011]] ([[Keiko Fujimori]]): 37 seats. *[[Possible Peru]] ([[Alejandro Toledo]]): 21 seats. *Alliance for the Great Change ([[Pedro Pablo Kuczynski]]): 12 seats. *[[National Solidarity (Peru)|Alliance National Solidarity]] ([[Luis Castañeda]]): 9 seats. *[[Peruvian Aprista Party]] ([[Alan Garcia Perez]]): 4 seats.
==Peruvian Congress of 2016-2021== {{main article|List of current members of the Congress of Peru|Peruvian general election, 2016}} *[[Popular Force]] ([[Keiko Fujimori]]): 73 seats. *[[Broad Front (Peru)|Broad Front]] ([[Verónika Mendoza]]): 20 seats. *[[Peruvians for Change]] ([[Pedro Pablo Kuczynski]]): 18 seats. *Alliance for Progress (César Acuña): 9 seats. *[[Popular Action (Peru)|Popular Action]] ([[Alfredo Barnechea]]): 5 seats. *[[Peruvian Aprista Party]] ([[Alan García Pérez]]): 5 seats.
[[Category:Government of Peru]] [[Category:Peru-related lists]]

'''Parliamentary elections''' were held in [[Hungary]] between 13 and 22 June 1884. The result was a victory for the [[Liberal Party (Hungary)|Liberal Party]], which won 234 of the 413 seats.
==Results== {| class="wikitable" !style="background:#CCDDEE; width: 18em" | Party !style="width: 5em; background:#CCDDEE;" | Seats !style="width: 5em; background:#CCDDEE;" | % !style="width: 7em; background:#CCDDEE;" | Parliamentary role |- | [[Liberal Party (Hungary)|Liberal Party]] | style="text-align:center" |234 | style="text-align:center" |56,52% |align=center style="background: #ddffdd"| government |- | [[Moderate Opposition]] | style="text-align:center" |64 | style="text-align:center" |15,46% |align=center style="background: #ffdddd"| opposition |- | [[National Independence Kossuth Party|Party of Independence and '48]] | style="text-align:center" |75 | style="text-align:center" |18,12% |align=center style="background: #ffdddd"| opposition |- | [[National Antisemitic Party]] | style="text-align:center" |17 | style="text-align:center" |4,12% |align=center style="background: #ffdddd"| opposition |- | [[Minorities' Party]] | style="text-align:center" |15 | style="text-align:center" |3,63% |align=center style="background: #ffffff"| opposition |- | Independent | style="text-align:center" |8 | style="text-align:center" |1,94% |align=center style="background: #ffffff"| independent |- |align=center style="background: lightgrey" | '''Total''' |align=center style="background: lightgrey" | '''413''' |align=center style="background: lightgrey" | '''100%''' |align=center style="background: lightgrey" | — |}

{{more citations needed|date=March 2014}} [[File:Arsinoitherium hharder.png|thumb|right|[[Heinrich Harder]]'s reconstruction of ''[[Arsinoitherium zitteli]]'' in the Oligocene grassland of [[Jebel Qatrani]] escarpment.]] The '''Jebel Qatrani Formation''' is a [[paleontology|palaeontological]] and [[geologic formation]] located in the [[Faiyum Governorate]] of central [[Egypt]].
Conformably{{check|date=November 2012}} overlying the [[Qasr el Sagha Formation]]. It is exposed namely between the [[Jebel Qatrani]] escarpment and the Qasr el Sagha [[escarpment]], north of [[Birket Qarun]] lake near [[Faiyum]].
==Geology== These rocks were laid down in the [[Eocene]]-[[Oligocene]] period ([[Priabonian]] - [[Rupelian]]){{check|date=November 2012}}. This formation was originally thought to be between 35.4 and 33.3 million years old, based on initial analysis of the formation. However, analysis by Erik Seiffert in 2006 concluded that the age of the Jebel Qatrani Formation should be revised. His assessment of more recent evidence indicates an age for most of the formation of between 30.2 and 29.5 million years ago, placing it almost entirely in the [[Rupelian|Early Oligocene]]. Seiffert states that only the lowest 48 metres was laid down in the [[Eocene]],<ref name="Seiffert">{{cite journal |author=Seiffert Erik R. |title=Revised age estimates for the later Paleogene mammal faunas of Egypt and Oman|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America |volume=103 |issue=13 |pages=5000–5005 |date=Jan 2006 | |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/103/13/5000.short| doi=10.1073/pnas.0600689103 |pmc=1458784}}</ref> but recent opinion holds the original hypothesis of a sediment straddling the Eocene-Oligocene boundary to be correct.{{Citation needed|reason=Cannot find any contradiction of Seiffert, everything found stating older appears to be from the 1990's, found one article published 2014 but that was an online republishing of Prothero&Berggren(1992)|date=October 2017}}
Mostly [[sandstone]]s deposited by meandering rivers and seasonal lakes, the lower (Eocene) part of the formation represents a woodlanded ecosystem of which lots of [[petrified wood]] also remain. In contrast, the upper (Oligocene) layers present indication of much drier and cooler conditions, with [[savanna]] replacing the woodland for several million years before the climate turned wetter and warmer again and the forests regrew.
The [[fauna]] changes also notably during this time, which seems to be coincident with the [[Eocene–Oligocene extinction event]] recorded in Eurasia.
==Fossils== [[File:Aegyptopithecus NT.jpg|thumb|right|Life restoration of prehistoric primate ''[[Aegyptopithecus zeuxis]]''.]] [[File:Bothriogenys fraasi.JPG|thumb|right|Reconstruction of Jebel Qatrani swamp forest at the end of the Eocene, with two ''[[Bothriogenys fraasi]]'' in front of an ''[[Arsinoitherium zitteli]]'']]
===Mammals=== * ''[[Arsinoitherium zitteli]]'', an arsinoitheriid * ''[[Bothriogenys fraasi]]'', an anthracotheriid * ''Herodotius pattersoni'', a [[pseudoungulate]] * ''[[Plesiopithecus]]'', an enigmatic lemur-like primate * [[Pliohyracidae]], large [[hyrax]]es * [[Ptolemaiida]], carnivorous [[Afrotheria|afrothere]] mammals * ''[[Qatranilestes]]'' and ''[[Widanelfarasia]]'', relatives of [[golden mole]]s, [[otter shrew]]s, and [[tenrec]]s * Several [[hyaenodontid]]s (''[[Akhnatenavus]] cf. leptognathus, [[Metapterodon]]'') * Several [[hystricognath]] rodents (e.g. ''[[Acritophiomys]] bowni, A. woodi, [[Elwynomys]] lavocati, [[Gaudeamus (rodent)|Gaudeamus]] hylaeus'') * A primitive [[marsupial]], maybe related to ''[[Peratherium]]'' * Primitive Old World [[monkey]]s (e.g. ''[[Aegyptopithecus zeuxis]], [[Biretia]] fayumensis'' & ''B. megalopsis'')
===Birds=== * ''[[Eremopezus]]'', an enigmatic large groundbird * ''[[Goliathia]]'', a large shoebill relative * ''[[Palaeoephippiorhynchus]] dietrichi'', a large stork * ''Xenerodiops'', an unusual [[heron]] * A [[cormorant]]-like bird, possibly related to genus ''Piscator'' * Several [[Jacanidae|jacana]]s * One or two species of primitive [[osprey]] and another [[bird of prey]] (possibly an ancestral [[sea eagle]]) * A [[turaco]]
===Other animals=== * ''[[Albertwoodemys]]'', a side-necked turtle * ''[[Crocodylus megarhinus|"Crocodylus" megarhinus]]'', an ancestral crocodile * ''[[Eogavialis africanum]]'', a primitive gharial * ''[[Parachanna fayumensis]]'', a snakehead fish * ''Pterosphenus'', a [[snake]] * [[African tetras]] (Alestidae) or similar [[Characiformes]] * [[Catfish]], perhaps of genus ''Fajumia''
== See also == * {{C|Geologic formations of Egypt}} * [[List of fossil sites]]
==References== <references /> * {{aut|Vickers-Rich, Patricia & Rich, Thomas Hewett}} (1993); ''Wildlife of Gondwana''. Reed. {{ISBN|0-7301-0315-3}}
{{-}}

Senegal | language = | budget = | gross = | screenplay = Mama Kéïta | cinematography = Remi Mazet | editing = Miriame Chamekh | music = Mathieur Normant }} '''''L'Absence ''''' is a 2009 film. == Synopsis == After doing brilliantly in his studies and a 15 year absence, Adama, a young polytechnician, rushes back to [[Senegal]], his home country, when he receives a [[telegram]] saying his grandmother is very ill. His brief stay will revive a family drama seemingly forgotten. The film reflects director Mama Keita's experience with African students who study abroad and are content to be spectators of the poverty and violence in Africa. == Awards == * [[Panafrican Film and Television Festival of Ouagadougou|Fespaco]] 2009 == References == {{RefFCAT|17}} * {{IMDb title|1520487}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Absence}} [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Senegalese films]] {{Senegal-film-stub}}

{{primary sources|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox film | name = Le Pèlerin de Camp Nou (a.k.a. Captain Majid) | image = | caption = | director = Abakar Chene Massar | producer = Bentley Brown | writer = Abakar Chene Massar | starring = Abakar Chene Massar
Ousman "Johnny" Adoum
Nadech Ngaryo
Adoudou Ahmat Aziber
Hamza Malloum Ali | music = Aaron Brown
Sosal Abakar | cinematography = Bentley Brown | editing = Bentley Brown | distributor = | country = [[Chad]] / [[U.S.]] | released = {{film date|2009|4|4|df=yes}} | runtime = 94 minutes | language = [[Chadian Arabic language|Chadian Arabic]], [[French language|French]] | budget = [[Euro|€]]1,200[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1391623/business ''Le Pèlerin de Camp Nou box office/business''], The Internet Movie Database (IMDB) }} '''Le Pèlerin de Camp Nou''' ([[English language|English]]: "Captain Majid") is a 2009 feature film produced in the north-central African country of Chad. A work of "no-budget" digital cinema, it experienced international release at the Festival du Film PanAfricain in Cannes, France, in April 2009, and was featured at festivals in Montreal, Toronto, and London in 2009 before screening at the International Film Festival Rotterdam in 2010.[http://www.festivaldufilmpanafricain.org/dossiers/dossiers.php?val=93_selection+officielle ''Sélection Officielle''] Festival du Film PanAfricain == Synopsis == Majid (Abakar Chene Massar) duels his own coach (Ousman Adoum) for the heart of team president's daughter Faiza (Nadech Ngaryo). Faiza, an avid football fan herself, makes her intentions clear: she will be devoted to one and one only. Majid is almost sidelined in the town championship game but manages to lead his team to victory. His dream of playing international football is matched in intensity only by a budding relationship with Faiza and the upcoming academic exams that will determine his future. All is at stake, however, when local drugs threaten to throw Majid into a downward spiral.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1391623/synopsis ''Le Pèlerin de Camp Nou synopsis''] The Internet Movie Database (IMDB) == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|1391623|Le Pèlerin de Camp Nou}} * {{Official website|http://aboudiginfilms.com}} * [http://www.filmfestivalrotterdam.com/en/films/le-p-lerin-de-camp-nou/ ''Le Pèlerin de Camp Nou at the International Film Festival Rotterdam''] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091101113623/http://www.africaatthepictures.co.uk/london-african-film-festival/captain-majid/ ''Le Pèlerin de Camp Nou at the London African Film Festival''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Pelerin De Camp Nou, Le}} [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:Chadian films]] {{Chad-film-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=October 2008}} [[File:Bulgaria-SanStefano -(1878)-byTodorBozhinov.png|thumb|A map which shows the territories of the liberated Bulgarian [[Tributary state]] in 1878 and its dividing at the same year with adoption of [[Treaty of Berlin (1878)|Treaty of Berlin]]]] In [[Bulgaria]]n [[historiography]], the '''liberation of Bulgaria''' refers to those events of the [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)]] that led to the re-establishment of the [[Bulgarians|Bulgarian]] [[Sovereign state|state]] under the [[Treaty of San Stefano]] of 3 March 1878.
The [[treaty]], championed and written by the honorable Peter, forced the [[Ottoman Empire]] give back to Bulgaria most of its territory conquered in 14th century. At the Berlin Congress of the same year, the [[Treaty of Berlin (1878)|Treaty of Berlin]] was adopted, according to which the territories of the Bulgarian state, established as per the San Stefano treaty, were divided into three parts: the first part was the [[Principality of Bulgaria]], which functioned independently but was nominally a [[Vassal state|vassal]] of the Ottoman Empire and was limited to [[Moesia]] and areas adjacent to the capital [[Sofia]]; the second part was to be an autonomous province of the Ottoman Empire—[[Eastern Rumelia]]; the third and largest part—all of the [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]] and [[Lozengrad]]—were restored to the Ottoman Empire while some outlands were assigned to Serbia and Romania. Those territories seized from Bulgaria after the Berlin Congress, including most of Macedonia, Thrace and others, had a majority ethnic Bulgarian population. On 6 September 1885, [[Bulgarian unification|Eastern Rumelia became part of the Principality of Bulgaria]] after a bloodless unification, although the principality was a ''[[de facto]]'' independent nation but ''[[de jure]]'' vassal nation of the Ottoman Empire until 1908, when Bulgaria proclaimed its [[Bulgarian Declaration of Independence|declaration of independence]].
The 1908 declaration, which signified Bulgaria's break with the [[Ottoman Bulgaria|Ottoman rule]], was actually the second liberation of Bulgaria. After the conquest of the [[First Bulgarian Empire]] in 1018, the first liberation of Bulgaria led to the establishment of the [[Second Bulgarian Empire]] in the aftermath of the [[Uprising of Asen and Peter]] against the [[Byzantine Empire]] in 1185.
== See also == * [[National awakening of Bulgaria]]

revision.text:
'''Optic Nerve''' is a [[mass surveillance]] programme run by the British [[signals intelligence]] agency [[Government Communications Headquarters]] (GCHQ), with help from the US [[National Security Agency]], that surreptitiously collects private [[webcam]] still images from users while they are using a [[Yahoo!]] [[webcam]] application. As an example of the scale, in one 6-month period, the programme is reported to have collected images from 1.8 million Yahoo! user accounts globally. The programme was first reported on in the media in February 2014, from documents leaked by the former [[National Security Agency]] contractor [[Edward Snowden]], but dates back to a prototype started in 2008, and was still active in at least 2012.<ref name="guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/27/gchq-nsa-webcam-images-internet-yahoo|title=Yahoo webcam images from millions of users intercepted by GCHQ|work=The Guardian|first=Spencer |last=Ackerman |first2=James |last2=Ball|date=27 February 2014|accessdate= 28 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=Perlroth-NYT/>
The leaked documents describe the users under surveillance as "unselected", meaning that data was collected indiscriminately in bulk from users regardless of whether they were an intelligence target or not. The vast majority of affected users would have been completely innocent of any crime or suspicion of a crime. Optic Nerve as described in the documents collected one still image every 5 minutes per user, attempting to comply with human rights legislation.<ref name="guardian" /> The images were collected in a searchable database, and used for experiments in [[Facial recognition system|facial recognition]], to monitor known targets, and to discover new targets. The choice of Yahoo! for surveillance was taken because "Yahoo webcam is known to be used by GCHQ targets". Unlike the US [[NSA]], the UK GCHQ is not required by law to minimize the collection from domestic citizens, so UK citizens could have been targeted on the same level as non-UK citizens.<ref name="guardian" /><ref name=Perlroth-NYT/>
The story was broken by ''[[The Guardian]]'' in February 2014, and is based on leaked documents dating to between 2008 and 2012. Yahoo! expressed outrage at the programme,<ref>{{Cite web |url = http://world.time.com/2014/02/27/nsa-leaks-edward-snowden-gchq-yahoo-webcam-spying/ | work = Time | title = Report: U.K. Spy Agency Stored Millions of Webcam Images| accessdate = 28 February 2014 | first = Denver| last = Nicks|date = 27 February 2014}}</ref> when approached by ''The Guardian'', and subsequently called it "a whole new level of violation of our users' privacy."<ref name="guardian" /> A GCHQ spokesperson stated "It is a long-standing policy that we do not comment on intelligence matters".<ref name=Perlroth-NYT/><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/27/us-usa-security-britain-idUSBREA1Q1XX20140227| publisher = Reuters|accessdate = 28 February 2014 | date = 27 February 2014 | first = Julia | last = Fioretti| title = British spy agency collected images of Yahoo! webcam chats: Guardian}}</ref>
Though there were some limits to which photos security analysts were allowed to see, with bulk searches limited to metadata, security analysts were allowed to see "webcam images associated with similar Yahoo identifiers to your known target".<ref name="guardian" /><ref name=Perlroth-NYT>{{cite news|last=Perlroth|first=Nicole|title=British Spies Said to Intercept Yahoo Webcam Images|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/28/technology/british-spies-said-to-have-intercepted-yahoo-webcam-images.html?hpw&rref=technology&_r=1|accessdate=28 February 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=27 February 2014}}</ref>
==Technical details== Optic Nerve worked by collecting the information from GCHQ's large network of [[network tap|Internet cable taps]], feeding into systems provided by the United States' [[National Security Agency]]. NSA research was used to build the tool to isolate the webcam traffic.<ref name="guardian" />
Given that both Yahoo! Messenger chats and webcam streams are sent unencrypted, it would have been relatively easy (though not trivial) to intercept the webcam traffic.<ref name="register">{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2014/02/27/gchq_optic_nerve/|title=UK spies on MILLIONS of Yahoo! webcams, ogles sex vids - report|publisher=The Register|date=27 February 2014|author=Jack Clark}}</ref> Following the Snowden leaks, Yahoo! planned to give all users the option to encrypt all communications with Yahoo!'s servers by April, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yahoo.tumblr.com/post/67373852814/our-commitment-to-protecting-your-information|title=Our Commitment to Protecting Your Information|publisher=Yahoo!}}</ref>
==Sexually explicit images== Between 3% and 11% of the images captured by the webcams were sexually explicit in nature <ref name="guardian" /> and deemed "undesirable nudity".<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/yahoo-webcam-users-intimate-images-intercepted-by-gchq-spy-programme-snowden-files-reveal-9158140.html | work = The Independent | accessdate = 28 February 2014 | date = 27 February 2014 | title = British agents spied on Yahoo users' 'intimate' webcam images, Snowden files reveal | first = Ian | last = Johnston}}</ref>
{{quote|Unfortunately … it would appear that a surprising number of people use webcam conversations to show intimate parts of their body to the other person. Also, the fact that the Yahoo! software allows more than one person to view a webcam stream without necessarily sending a reciprocal stream means that it appears sometimes to be used for broadcasting pornography.}}
==Other webcam traffic targets== The documents mentioned interest in monitoring the video from the [[Xbox 360]] and [[Xbox One]]'s [[Kinect]] camera,<ref name="guardian" /> something which [[Microsoft]] has reported it was oblivious to.<ref>{{cite web|title=GCHQ identified Kinect as possible snooping tool; Microsoft denies all knowledge|url=http://www.mcvuk.com/news/read/gchq-identified-kinect-as-possible-snooping-tool/0128871|work=The Market for Computer and Video Games|accessdate=1 March 2014}}</ref>
==Reactions== {{quote|This is a truly shocking revelation that underscores the importance of the debate on privacy now taking place and the reforms being considered. In a world in which there is no technological barrier to pervasive surveillance, the scope of the government’s surveillance activities must be decided by the public, not secretive spy agencies interpreting secret legal authorities.|The [[American Civil Liberties Union]]<ref name="register" />}}
==See also== * [[Camfecting]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Mass surveillance]] [[Category:Government Communications Headquarters operations]] [[Category:Yahoo!]] [[Category:Video surveillance]] [[Category:Webcams]]
