revision.text:
{{Other uses|Public Eye (disambiguation){{!}}Public Eye}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} The '''Public Eye on Davos''', held every year between 2000 and 2015, was a counter-event to the annual meeting of the [[World Economic Forum]] in [[Davos]].
The project involved [[non-governmental organizations]] (NGOs) from around the world and was coordinated by Swiss organizations [[Erklärung von Bern]] (EvB, renamed "Public Eye" in 2016) and [[Greenpeace]] Switzerland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evb.ch/en/f25001565.html |title=Berne Declaration - Public Eye Awards 2009 |publisher=Evb.ch |date= |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> The Public Eye is a platform for substantial criticism of "purely profit-oriented globalization".<ref name="publiceyeawards.ch"/> The focus of the Public Eye Awards since 2005 has been on [[corporate social responsibility]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evb.ch/en/p14518.html |title=Berne Declaration - Public Eye Awards 2009 |publisher=Evb.ch |date= |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> In 2009, the Positive category was for the first time awarded for a courageous employee for his or her exemplary contributions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evb.ch/cm_data/Nominationsaufruf_e.pdf |title=Zurich, August 118,2008 - open letter |publisher=Evb.ch |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref>
== History == The Public Eye was first hold in the year 2000 to accompany the [[World Economic Forum]] (WEF) in [[Davos]] critically. Together with the newspaper [[WOZ Die Wochenzeitung|WOZ]] they organized an event under the name ″Who rules the world″ and organized a public discussion with the president of the WEF, [[Klaus Schwab]].<ref>[http://www.lora.ch/events/davos/wef2000/events.htm ''Auf nach Davos.''] Event Calendar of the [[Radio LoRa|Radio Lora]]. Visited on the 8.6.2018.</ref> In the following year the Public Eye was extended to a multiple day counter-conference with 20 participants from [[NGO]]s and critical scientists. They also followed the WEF to New York in 2002, where the [[President of the Swiss Confederation]], [[Kaspar Villiger]], opened the conference.<ref>{{cite web |author=Michael Hollingdale |url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/new-york-prepares-for-the-wef-and-public-eye/2515826 |title=New York prepares for the WEF and Public Eye |publisher=[[Swissinfo]] |date=2002-01-21 |accessdate=2016-10-06}}</ref>
In 2005 they introduced the Public Eye Awards as a renewal of the event, which was in future the main event of the Public Eye on Davos. In 2007, after [[Pro Natura (Switzerland)|Pro Natura]] stopped working on the event because the use of the event was too one-sited on the organizers of the WEF, [[Greenpeace]] was beside [[Erklärung von Bern]] the new organizing partner of the event.<ref>[https://zeitungsarchiv.nzz.ch/neue-zuercher-zeitung-vom-25-01-2007-seite-25.html Neue Zürcher Zeitung from 25 January 2007, page 25]</ref> The Public Eye celebrated its ten-year anniversary on 28 January 2009.<ref name="publiceyeawards.ch">{{cite web|author=Feinheit |url=http://www.publiceyeawards.ch/de/p63000130.html |title=Public Eye Awards kriegen Unterstützung von renommierten Wirtschaftsethikern - Public Eye Awards 2012 |language=de |publisher=Publiceyeawards.ch |date=2012-01-05 |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> In 2015, Davos was for the last time the venue of the Public Eye Award with [[Chevron Corporation]] as winner of the lifetime award.<ref name="schweizaktuell-20150116">{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/sendungen/schweiz-aktuell/fixer-eurokurs-im-wallis-wef-ohne-demos|title=WEF ohne Kritiker|publisher=[[Schweiz aktuell]]|author=|language=German|date=2015-01-16|accessdate=2015-01-17}}</ref><ref name="evb-bibidavos">{{cite web|url=https://www.evb.ch/medien/medienmitteilung/public_eye_davoser_abschiedsfeuerwerk_mit_lifetime_award_und_den_yes_men/|title=Public Eye: Davoser Abschiedsfeuerwerk mit "Lifetime Award" und den Yes Men|publisher=[[Erklärung von Bern]]|author=|language=German|date=2014-11-19|accessdate=2015-01-17}}</ref>
== Laureates == {{Infobox award | name = Public Eye Award | subheader = <!-- or | current_awards = --> | image = Public Eye Awards 2008 (cropped).jpg | image_size = <!-- or | image_upright = --> | alt = | caption = | description = Purely profit-oriented globalisation (bad corporate environmental or [[corporate social responsibility|social responsibility]]) | sponsor = | date = 2000-2015 | location = | country = [[Switzerland]] | presenter = [[Public Eye (Erklärung von Bern)|Public Eye]] and (since 2009) [[Greenpeace]] Switzerland | host = <!-- or | hosts = --> | former name = | preshow_host = | acts = | reward = | year = | year2 = | holder_label = | holder = <!-- or | winner = or | winners = --> | most_awards = <!-- or | most_wins = --> | most_nominations = | award1_type = | award1_winner = | award2_type = | award2_winner = | award3_type = | award3_winner = | award4_type = | award4_winner = | award5_type = | award5_winner = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | network = <!-- or | network_list = --> | runtime = | viewership = <!-- or | ratings = --> | producer = | director = | image2 = | image2size = <!-- or | image_upright2 --> | alt2 = | caption2 = | previous = | main = | next = }} === 2015 === *Winner of the Lifetime Award: [[Chevron Corporation]] Chevron was 'awarded' namely for its activities of the past 10 years in Bolivia, that caused enormous ecological damage.<ref name="tagesschau-20150123-6pm">{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/sendungen/tagesschau|title=Tagesschau 23 January 2015 at 18:00|publisher=Swiss Television SRF|author=|language=German|date=2015-01-23|accessdate=2015-01-23}}</ref>
According to [[Schweiz aktuell]] broadcast on 16 January 2015, a public presence during the WEF 2015 may not be guaranteed because the massively increased security in Davos. The Public Eye Award will be awarded for the last time in Davos: ''Public Eyes says Goodbye to Davos'', confirmed by the Rolf Marugg (now ''Landrats'' politician), by not directly enganed politicians, and by the police responsible.<ref name="schweizaktuell-20150116"/> As communicated before by [[Erklärung von Bern]] on 19 November 2014, following the announcement of the ''Lifetime Award'' winner on 23 January 2015, a closing conference will be hold, with the participation of the ''[[Yes Men]]'', [[Sven Giegold]], the [[Attac]] co-founder and [[Members of the European Parliament 2009–14|European Parliamentarian]], and [[Adrian Monck]] as Managing Director und Head of Public Engagement of the WEF association, as well as [[Noreena Hertz]], economy professor and best-selling author.<ref name="evb-bibidavos"/>
=== 2014 ===
*Winners: [[Gazprom]], [[Gap Inc.|Gap]]
In December 2013, Gazprom became the first company in the world to start drilling for oil in the Arctic Barents Sea. Since the drilling began, the corporation has already violated several federal safety and environmental regulations. Fashion giant Gap has refused to sign the binding agreement «Accord on Fire and Building Safety in Bangladesh». Instead, it is actively undermining serious reform by promoting a non-binding corporate-controlled program.<ref name="woz-20140109">{{cite web|url=http://www.woz.ch/1402/public-eye-awards/koenige-der-ausbeuter|title=Public Eye Awards: Könige der Ausbeuter|publisher=[[WOZ Die Wochenzeitung]] 02/2014|author=Mario Walser|language=German|date=2014-01-09|accessdate=2014-12-15}}</ref>
=== 2013 ===
*Winners: People's Award: [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]], Jury Award: [[Goldman Sachs]]
Nominees were [[Coal India]], [[G4S]], [[Lonmin]], and [[Repower (Swiss energy utility)|Repower]]
=== 2012 === * Winners: People's award: [[Vale (mining company)|Vale]], Jury award: [[Barclays]] Nominees were [[Freeport-McMoRan|Freeport]], [[TEPCO]], [[Samsung]] and [[Syngenta]]
=== 2011 === * Audience award: [[Neste Oil]], Jury award: [[AngloGold Ashanti]] Nominees were [[Axpo]] (a Swiss energy company), [[BP]], [[Foxconn]] and [[Philip Morris International|Philip Morris]]
=== 2010 === * Winners: 2x [[Hoffmann–La Roche|Roche]] (Swiss, People), [[Royal Bank of Canada]] (Global), water mandate of [[United Nations Global Compact|UN Global Compact]] (Greenwash)
The Public Eye Award in the category Swiss and People was given to the Swiss health care-company for the selling of the drug [[Cellcept]] in China, where over 90% of the organs for transplantation comes from executed prisoners - against their own will.
Nominees: [[International Olympic Committee]]
=== 2009 === * Winners: 2x [[Newmont Mining Corporation]] (Global, People), [[BKW FMB Energie AG]] (Swiss) * Positive Award: Freddy Lozano and Jairo Quiroz Delgado, executive members from the [[trade union]] [[Sintracarbon]].
Newmont received the 2009 award for its Akyem project in Ghana. According to the jury it had destroyed unique natural habitats, carried out forced resettlement of local people and polluted soil and rivers.<ref name="ips2009-01-30">{{cite web|url=http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=45618|title=Davos Under Fire|last=Capdevila|first=Gustavo|date=2009-01-30|publisher=Inter Press Service|accessdate=16 September 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610230132/http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=45618|archivedate=10 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publiceyeawards.ch/media/medialibrary/2010/01/Newmont_Mining_Corporation_WACAM_new.pdf |title=Newmont Mining Corporation |publisher=Publiceyeawards.ch |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> Newmont described the information as misleading and said the project had been extensively studied by international and national environmental experts, members of the local communities, and by the appropriate governmental agencies and departments.<ref name="aa2009-02-02">{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200902021142.html|title=Ghana: Newmont Responds to 'Public Eye Award'|last=Nonor|first=Daniel|date=2009-02-02|publisher=allAfrica.com|accessdate=16 September 2010}}</ref>
BWFK FMB Energie AG received the Swiss Award for their participation at German coal-burning power plants and the same time propagation of power efficiency and renewable energy in Switzerland.
The positive Award was given to two members of the union Sintracarbon in Colombia for their fight for better work conditions for the workers in the country's biggest coal mine ([[El Cerrejón]]).
=== 2008 === [[File:Public Eye Awards 2008 mit Melanie Winiger.jpg|thumb|[[Melanie Winiger]] at the Public Eye Awards 2008.]]
* Winners: 2x [[Areva]] (Global, People), [[Glencore]] (Swiss) * Positive Award: Hess Natur
Both the People’s Award and the Global Award were given to French state-owned Areva for the suppression of true health conditions of uranium mine workers at subsidiaries Somaïr and Cominak in northern Niger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evb.ch/cm_data/Areva_1.pdf |title=AREVA Gruppe S.A. |publisher=Evb.ch |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> Therefore, the hospitals would diagnose patients with [[HIV]] when they were actually displaying symptoms of [[Radiation-induced cancer|cancer caused by radioactive contamination]] of air, water and soil. Glencore was "honored" for its opaque business practices and unacceptable labor rights in Colombian coal mines.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.evb.ch/cm_data/Glencore_1.pdf |title=Glencore International AG |publisher=Evb.ch |accessdate=2012-11-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110531224542/http://www.evb.ch/cm_data/Glencore_1.pdf |archivedate=31 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The Positive Award went to Hess Natur, Germany’s largest mail-order house for natural fabrics, for its social and ecological involvement that stresses fair trade of its raw materials.
=== 2007 === * Winners: [[Bridgestone]] (Global), [[Novartis]] (Swiss) * Positive Award: [[Coop (Switzerland)]]
Bridgestone received the Global Award for the disastrous working conditions at a subsidiary in [[Liberia]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Feinheit |url=http://www.publiceyeawards.ch/de/p63000017.html?cm_style=content |title=Public Eye Awards kriegen Unterstützung von renommierten Wirtschaftsethikern - Public Eye Awards 2012 |language=de |publisher=Publiceyeawards.ch |date=2012-01-05 |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> The workers lived in mud huts, the children were forced to work, and they had to handle highly toxic materials without protection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evb.ch/p11801.html?cm_style=big |title=Erklärung von Bern - Die Gewinner 2007 |language=de |publisher=[[Erklärung von Bern]]|date= |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> Novartis received the Swiss Award for the patenting of the cancer drug Imatinib, forcing a halt in production of Indian generics. As a result, ten thousand patients worldwide could no longer afford medication that slowed the spread of leukemia.<ref>{{cite web|author=Feinheit |url=http://www.publiceyeawards.ch/de/p63000021.html?cm_style=content |title=Public Eye Awards kriegen Unterstützung von renommierten Wirtschaftsethikern - Public Eye Awards 2012 |language=de |publisher=Publiceyeawards.ch |date=2012-01-05 |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> The product from Novartis is ten times more expensive than the generics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evb.ch/cm_data/Novartis_e.pdf |title=Novartis AG |publisher=Evb.ch |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref>
Coop received the Positive Award for its dedication to ecological products and farming in Switzerland.
=== 2006 === * Winners: [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] (Environment), [[citigroup]] (Taxes), [[The Walt Disney Company]] (Social) * Positive Award: Euzkadi Union SNRTE, [[Germanwatch]] and [[Food First Information and Action Network|FIAN]]
For 30 years, Chevron allowed highly toxic waste water to flow into the [[Amazon Rainforest|Amazon]] in [[Ecuador]], and for cost-saving reasons it did not pump the waste water back into the earth, which was normal practice at the time.<ref>{{cite web|author=Feinheit |url=http://www.publiceyeawards.ch/de/p63000022.html?cm_style=content |title=Public Eye Awards kriegen Unterstützung von renommierten Wirtschaftsethikern - Public Eye Awards 2012 |language=de |publisher=Publiceyeawards.ch |date=2012-01-05 |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> Chevron refuses to pay for the environmental consequences and the health problems of the local communities.<ref name="evb.ch">{{cite web|url=http://www.evb.ch/p10605.html |title=Erklärung von Bern - Die Gewinner 2006 |language=de |publisher=Evb.ch |date= |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> Citigroup received its award for the unscrupulous advice it gave to tax evaders. Disney produces toys in China and does not disclose the names of the suppliers, thus protecting them from industry monitoring.<ref name="evb.ch"/>
The Positive Award was given to the three organizations for their efforts against the unlawful closure of a Continental tire factory in Mexico, in which all of the organizations’ demands were met.
=== 2005 === * Winners: [[Dow Chemical|Dow]] (Human Rights), [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] (Environment), [[Wal-Mart]] (Labor Rights), [[KPMG]] (Taxes)
Dow received its award for the refusal to accept any responsibility for the [[Bhopal disaster|1984 catastrophe in Bhopal]]. Dow merged with the company responsible for the accident.<ref>{{cite web|author=Feinheit |url=http://www.publiceyeawards.ch/de/p63000016.html?cm_style=content |title=Public Eye Awards kriegen Unterstützung von renommierten Wirtschaftsethikern - Public Eye Awards 2012 |language=de |publisher=Publiceyeawards.ch |date=2012-01-05 |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> Shell received its award for gas flaring in Nigeria in residential areas.<ref>{{cite web|author=Feinheit |url=http://www.publiceyeawards.ch/de/p63000024.html?cm_style=content |title=Public Eye Awards kriegen Unterstützung von renommierten Wirtschaftsethikern - Public Eye Awards 2012 |language=de |publisher=Publiceyeawards.ch |date=2012-01-05 |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> Wal-Mart denies responsibility for working conditions at its suppliers.<ref>{{cite web|author=Feinheit |url=http://www.publiceyeawards.ch/de/p63000020.html?cm_style=content |title=Public Eye Awards kriegen Unterstützung von renommierten Wirtschaftsethikern - Public Eye Awards 2012 |language=de |publisher=Publiceyeawards.ch |date=2012-01-05 |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> KPMG received its award for encouraging its clients to practice aggressive tax evasion.<ref>{{cite web|author=Feinheit |url=http://www.publiceyeawards.ch/de/p63000034.html?cm_style=content |title=Public Eye Awards kriegen Unterstützung von renommierten Wirtschaftsethikern - Public Eye Awards 2012 |language=de |publisher=Publiceyeawards.ch |date=2012-01-05 |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref>

{{primary sources |date=April 2018}} {{Infobox Radio Station | name = RTBF International | image = RTBF International logo.png | image_size = 200px | area = [[Europe]], [[Central Africa]] | airdate = 1 April 2004 | frequency = | format = | owner = [[RTBF]] | website = [http://www.rtbfi.be/ www.rtbfi.be] }}
'''RTBF International''' is the [[Belgium|Belgian]] ([[Wallonia]]) and ([[Brussels]]) international radio station owned by [[RTBF]], available in [[Europe]] and [[Central Africa]] via satellite and online.
On 26 June 2006, RTBF International began broadcasting in [[Frequency modulation|FM]] in [[Kinshasa]] on 99.2 [[MHz]].
RTBF ceased its [[shortwave]] service on December 31, 2009.
Although RTBF ceased its international service, it continues broadcasting from the Wavre transmitter on 621 [[kHz]], everyday from 05:00 - 23:00, in [[Amplitude modulation|AM]] with [[La Première]] broadcasting from 05:00 - 19:00, 23:00-00:00 (Monday - Friday) 06:00-14:00 (Weekend), and [[VivaCité]] broadcasting the rest of the time. It has been announced that this [[Medium wave|Medium Wave]] service shall cease before the end of 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telepro.be/011-43472-RTBF-la-fin-des-Ondes-moyennes-est-programmee.html|title=RTBF : la fin des Ondes moyennes est programmée ! {{!}} Infos Télévision {{!}} Télépro|website=Télépro|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref>
==See also== *[[RTBF]] *[[La Première]] *[[VivaCité]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-49 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1989-097A | SATCAT = 20361 | mission_duration = 7.5 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block II]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|840|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|11 December 1989, 18:10:01|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II|Delta II 6925]],}} D190 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17B]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = {{end-date|23 February 2005}} | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|20009|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20357|km}} | orbit_inclination = 54.9 degrees | orbit_period = 718 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-49''', also known as '''GPS II-5''' and '''GPS SVN-17''', was an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which formed part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the fifth of nine [[GPS Block II|Block II]] GPS satellites to be launched, which were the first operational GPS satellites to fly. USA-49 was launched at 18:10:01 UTC on 11 December 1989, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D190, flying in the 6925 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17B]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} and placed USA-49 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37XFP]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2.htm|title=GPS-2 (Navstar-2)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=10 July 2012}} On 11 January 1990, USA-49 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|20009|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20357|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 718 minutes, and 54.9 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It operated in slot 3 of plane D of the GPS constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/project/navstar.htm|title=Navstar|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]]|first=Mark|last=Wade|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The satellite had a mass of {{convert|840|kg}}, and generated 710 watts of power.{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1989-097A|title=Navstar 2-05|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It had a design life of 7.5 years, and ceased operations on 23 February 2005. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1989}} [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1989]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

{{ref improve|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = World Hepatitis Day |type = international |longtype = |image =WHD Globe.jpg |image_size = |caption = The World Hepatitis Day logo is the global symbol for encouraging better [[awareness]], action, and support to prevent and treat viral hepatitis. |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |scheduling = same day each year |date = 28 July |celebrations = |relatedto = }} '''World Hepatitis Day''', observed on July 28 every year, aims to [[raising awareness|raise global awareness]] of [[hepatitis]] — a group of infectious diseases known as Hepatitis [[hepatitis A|A]], [[hepatitis B|B]], [[hepatitis C|C]], [[Hepatitis D|D]], and [[Hepatitis E|E]] — and encourage prevention, diagnosis and treatment. Hepatitis affects hundreds of millions of people worldwide, causing acute and chronic disease and killing close to 1.4 million people every year.<ref name=WHOcampaign>World Health Organization, [http://www.who.int/campaigns/hepatitis-day/2013/en/ World Hepatitis Day.] Accessed 8 April 2014.</ref>
World Hepatitis Day is one of eight official [[global health|global public health]] campaigns marked by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), along with [[World Health Day]], [[World Blood Donor Day]], [[World Immunization Week]], [[World Tuberculosis Day]], [[World No Tobacco Day]], [[World Malaria Day]] and [[World AIDS Day]].<ref>World Health Organization, [http://www.who.int/campaigns/en WHO campaigns.]</ref>
==Background== Hepatitis groups, patients and advocates worldwide take part in events on 28 July. Notably in 2012, a Guinness World Record was created when 12,588 people from 20 countries did the [[Three Wise Monkeys]] actions on World Hepatitis Day to signify the willful ignorance of the disease.{{cn|date=June 2017}}
==History== The inaugural International Hepatitis C Awareness day, coordinated by various European and Middle Eastern Patient Groups and Baby Muriel, took place on October 1, 2004,<ref name=":0">http://www.elpa-info.org/index.php/general-news---reader/items/id-500-million-people-await-world-health-assembly-decision-on-viral-hepatitis.htm</ref> However many patient groups continued to mark 'hepatitis day' on disparate dates.<ref name="url">{{cite press release|title=World Hepatitis Alliance Calls on Governments to Take Urgent Action to Tackle Chronic Viral Hepatitis B & C Epidemic; 2008|url=http://www.aminumber12.org/Content/PDF/news_0004.pdf|work=World Hepatitis Day: Home Page|publisher=World Hepatitis Alliance|accessdate=2008-08-18}}</ref> For this reason in 2008, the World Hepatitis Alliance in collaboration with patient groups declared May 19 the first global World Hepatitis Day.
Following the adoption of a resolution during the 63rd [[World Health Assembly]] in May 2010, World Hepatitis Day was given global endorsement as the primary focus for national and international awareness-raising efforts and the date was changed to July 28 (in honour of Nobel Laureate [[Baruch Samuel Blumberg]], discoverer of the hepatitis B virus, who celebrates his birthday on that date). The resolution resolves that "28 July shall be designated as World Hepatitis Day in order to provide an [[right to education|opportunity for education]] and greater understanding of [[viral hepatitis]] as a global public health problem, and to stimulate the strengthening of preventive and control measures of this disease in Member States."
World Hepatitis Day is now recognised in over 100 countries each year through events such as free screenings, poster campaigns, demonstrations, concerts, talk shows, flash mobs and vaccination drives, amongst many others.<ref>World Hepatitis Alliance, [http://www.worldhepatitisalliance.org/en/world-hepatitis-day-2012.html ''World Hepatitis Day Wrap-Up Report 2012''.]</ref> Each year a report is published by the WHO and the World Hepatitis Alliance detailing all the events across the world.
==Themes==
World Hepatitis Day provides an opportunity to focus on actions such as:<ref name=WHOcampaign/> *Raising awareness of the different forms of hepatitis and how they are transmitted; *Strengthening prevention, screening and control of viral hepatitis and its related diseases; *Increasing hepatitis B vaccine coverage and integration into national immunization programmes; and *Coordinating a global response to hepatitis.
Each year focuses on a specific theme. The list of themes is as follows: * '''2011''': Hepatitis affects everyone, everywhere. Know it. Confront it. Confront her. * '''2012''': It’s closer than you think. * '''2013''': More must be done to stop this silent killer. * '''2014''': Hepatitis: Think Again * '''2015''': Prevention of viral Hepatitis. Act now.<ref>{{cite web|title=World Hepatitis Day 2015 to focus on prevention|url=http://www.who.int/hiv/mediacentre/news/whd2015_preventhepatitis/en/|publisher=World Health organization|accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref> * '''2016''': Know Hepatitis-Act now.<ref>http://worldhepatitisday.org/en/about-us</ref> * '''2017''': Eliminate Hepatities.<ref>{{citation |url=http://worldhepatitisday.org/en/2017-campaign |title=World Hepatities Day 2017 |accessdate=30 Nov 2017}}</ref> * '''2018''': Test. Treat. Hepatitis.<ref>{{cite web |title=World Hepatitis Day 28 July 2018 |url=http://www.who.int/who-campaigns/world-hepatitis-day/2018 |website=who.int |publisher=World Health Organization |accessdate=28 July 2018}}</ref>
